name: Takayasu Arteritis
description: Large vessel vasculitis primarily affecting the aorta and its major branches in young women. Characterized by granulomatous inflammation causing stenosis, occlusion, and aneurysm. Named for Japanese ophthalmologist Mikito Takayasu.

statement.text: Takayasu arteritis is a chronic, granulomatous large-vessel vasculitis primarily affecting the aorta and its major branches in young women, characterized by a systemic inflammatory phase followed by an occlusive/stenotic phase causing upper extremity claudication, absent pulses, and end-organ ischemia.
statement.formal: Takayasu Arteritis: Large Vessel Vasculitis → Aorta/Branches → Young Asian Female → Systemic Phase (ESR↑, Fever) → Occlusive Phase (Pulseless, Stenosis, Claudication) → Immunosuppression + Bypass

explanation.intuition: Takayasu's is an autoimmune attack on the body's largest blood vessels. The inflammation causes the aortic wall to thicken and scar, eventually blocking blood flow. It's called 'pulseless disease' because the arm pulses disappear as the arteries narrow.
explanation.key_insight: The disease has two phases: an early systemic phase with fever, fatigue, and high inflammatory markers, followed by an occlusive phase with vascular stenosis. Treatment differs by phase - immunosuppression during inflammation, revascularization during quiescent disease.
explanation.technical_details: Angiographic classification: Type I (branches from arch), Type IIa (ascending, arch, branches), Type IIb (adds descending), Type III (descending/abdominal/renal), Type IV (abdominal only), Type V (combined). Surgery/endovascular best performed during disease quiescence.

epidemiology.geography: Higher incidence in Asia (Japan, India, China)

prepulseless_phase.features: Constitutional symptoms - fever, malaise, weight loss, arthralgias

vascular_manifestations.upper_extremity: Arm claudication, absent pulses, BP discrepancy >10 mmHg
vascular_manifestations.pulmonary: Pulmonary artery involvement (rare, more in Japan)

characteristic_signs: Bruits over carotids, subclavians, abdominal aorta

criteria: Bruit over subclavian arteries or aorta

laboratory.esr: Elevated (but may be normal in burned-out disease)

clinical_pearls: Pulseless disease in young Asian woman = Takayasu
Check BP in BOTH arms - discrepancy is diagnostic clue
PET-CT can detect active inflammation even with normal ESR
Operate during REMISSION, not active inflammation
learning_objectives: Apply ACR criteria for Takayasu arteritis diagnosis
Describe the phases of disease and their clinical features
Explain optimal timing for surgical intervention

related.relationship: Similar large vessel vasculitis but older age group

sources.citation: Arend WP, et al. The American College of Rheumatology 1990 criteria for the classification of Takayasu arteritis. Arthritis Rheum. 1990;33(8):1129-1134
